TypeSignature.Value: .class public auto ansi beforefieldinit ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider extends System.Web.Security.MembershipProvider

Docs.summary: Enables forms authentication with client application services.

remarks.format:
## Remarks You can use client application services to validate users by using forms authentication. To enable forms authentication, you configure your application to use the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider> class. For more information, see [How to: Configure Client Application Services](~/docs/framework/common-client-technologies/how-to-configure-client-application-services.md).
After configuration, you can validate users by calling the `static` <xref:System.Web.Security.Membership.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method, which internally calls the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ValidateUser%28System.String%2CSystem.String%29?displayProperty=nameWithType> method.
Forms authentication requires that the user specify their credentials through login controls provided by your application. You can retrieve the credentials and pass them to the <xref:System.Web.Security.Membership.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method. You can also pass in empty strings or `null` to use a credentials provider. A credentials provider is an <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.IClientFormsAuthenticationCredentialsProvider> implementation specified in your application configuration file. You will typically implement the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.IClientFormsAuthenticationCredentialsProvider.GetCredentials%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method to display a login dialog box and return a populated <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationCredentials> object. Using a credentials provider enables you to share a single login dialog box among multiple applications.
The <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method authenticates users through the login service indicated by the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ServiceUri%2A> property. The value of the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ServiceUri%2A> property is typically retrieved from the application configuration file along with other configuration values. For more information, see [How to: Configure Client Application Services](~/docs/framework/common-client-technologies/how-to-configure-client-application-services.md).
If the user is successfully authenticated, the service provider sets the `static` <xref:System.Threading.Thread.CurrentPrincipal%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> property to a new <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.ClientRolePrincipal> object that contains a new <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.ClientFormsIdentity> object that contains the user information. If a <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientRoleProvider> is configured for your application, you can use the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.ClientRolePrincipal> object to retrieve user role information from the roles service.
You can retrieve a reference to the current <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider> instance through the `static` <xref:System.Web.Security.Membership.Provider%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> property. You can use the membership provider reference to call the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method directly. Additionally, you will need the membership provider reference to call the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.Logout%2A> method, which is not available in the <xref:System.Web.Security.MembershipProvider> base class.
You cannot use the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider> class to create, delete, or modify membership information. To create, delete, or modify users, you must change the configuration of the login service on the server.
## Examples The following example code demonstrates how to use this method to validate the user by using an <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.IClientFormsAuthenticationCredentialsProvider> implementation.
[!code-csharp[ClientApplicationServices#306](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/ClientApplicationServices/CS/Class1.cs#306)] [!code-vb[ClientApplicationServices#306](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/ClientApplicationServices/VB/Class1.vb#306)]

Docs.related: How to: Configure Client Application Services
How to: Implement User Login and Logout with Client Application Services

Docs.param: The friendly name of the provider.
A collection of name/value pairs representing the provider-specific attributes specified in the configuration for this provider.
Docs.summary: Initializes the provider.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The [!INCLUDE[vstecasp](~/includes/vstecasp-md.md)] extensibility model calls the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.Initialize%2A> method to initialize the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider> using information in your application configuration file. This method recognizes the following authentication service configuration attributes:
- `name`
- `description`
- `savePasswordHashLocally`
- `credentialsProvider`
- `connectionStringName`
- `serviceUri`
For more information, see [How to: Configure Client Application Services](~/docs/framework/common-client-technologies/how-to-configure-client-application-services.md).

Docs.exception:
is empty.
-or-
contains an unrecognized value.
Docs.related: How to: Configure Client Application Services

MemberSignature.Value: public void Logout ();
.method public hidebysig instance void Logout() cil managed
Public Sub Logout ()
public: void Logout();
member this.Logout : unit -> unit

Docs.summary: Logs out the user.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.Logout%2A> method clears all authentication cookies from the cookie cache and resets the `static` <xref:System.Threading.Thread.CurrentPrincipal%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> property to a <xref:System.Security.Principal.WindowsPrincipal> object that contains the current <xref:System.Security.Principal.WindowsIdentity>.
After you call this method, the current user is no longer authenticated for client application services. This means that you cannot retrieve roles through the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientRoleProvider> class and settings through the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientSettingsProvider> class. However, because the user might have a valid Windows identity, you might still receive a `true` value from code such as the following: `Thread.CurrentPrincipal.Identity.IsAuthenticated`. To determine whether the user is authenticated for client application services, confirm that the <xref:System.Security.Principal.IPrincipal.Identity%2A> property value of the <xref:System.Security.Principal.IPrincipal> retrieved through the `static` <xref:System.Threading.Thread.CurrentPrincipal%2A> property is a <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.ClientFormsIdentity> reference. Then, check the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.ClientFormsIdentity.IsAuthenticated%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> property.
To reauthenticate the current user, call the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method or the `static` <xref:System.Web.Security.Membership.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method.
## Examples The following example code demonstrates how to use this method to log out the user.
[!code-csharp[ClientApplicationServices#070](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/ClientApplicationServices/CS/Form1.cs#070)] [!code-vb[ClientApplicationServices#070](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/ClientApplicationServices/VB/Form1.vb#070)]

Docs.exception: The property value is and the membership provider is unable to access the authentication service.

remarks.format:
## Remarks The <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider> class always provides three password attempts. You cannot modify the provider to change the number of password attempts.
You cannot create, delete, or modify user information by using the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider> class.

Docs.summary: Gets or sets the URI of the authentication service.

remarks.format:
## Remarks You can set the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientRoleProvider.ServiceUri%2A> property in your application code, but you will typically set the value in your application configuration file. This enables you to change the service location without recompiling your code.
## Examples The following example code demonstrates how to use this property to programmatically set the authentication service location. When you set the service location programmatically, you must specify the complete service URI, which will always end with "Authentication_JSON_AppService.axd".
[!code-csharp[ClientApplicationServices#301](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/ClientApplicationServices/CS/Class1.cs#301)] [!code-vb[ClientApplicationServices#301](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/ClientApplicationServices/VB/Class1.vb#301)]

Docs.exception: When getting this property, no service URI was found in the application configuration file, and this property has not been previously set.
Docs.related: How to: Configure Client Application Services

MemberSignature.Value: public event EventHandler<System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.UserValidatedEventArgs> UserValidated;
.event class System.EventHandler`1<class System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.UserValidatedEventArgs> UserValidated
Public Event UserValidated As EventHandler(Of UserValidatedEventArgs)
public: event EventHandler<System::Web::ClientServices::Providers::UserValidatedEventArgs ^> ^ UserValidated;
member this.UserValidated : EventHandler<System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.UserValidatedEventArgs>

Docs.summary: Occurs when the user is validated.

remarks.format:
## Remarks This event occurs only after the user is successfully validated. You can use this event to update your application to reflect the current user. For example, you can use the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.UserValidatedEventArgs.UserName%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> property to display the user name in your application user interface (UI).
You can silently revalidate users by calling the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.ClientFormsIdentity.RevalidateUser%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method. Therefore, you should avoid using the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.UserValidated> event to display intrusive UI. For example, you should not use the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.UserValidated> event to display a welcome dialog box.
## Examples The following example code demonstrates how to use this event to display the user name in the title bar of a form.
[!code-csharp[ClientApplicationServices#305](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/ClientApplicationServices/CS/Class1.cs#305)] [!code-vb[ClientApplicationServices#305](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/ClientApplicationServices/VB/Class1.vb#305)]

Docs.summary: Authenticates a user by using the specified credentials.

Docs.returns: if the user was authenticated; otherwise, .

remarks.format:
## Remarks You can use client application services to validate users by using forms authentication. To validate users, you will typically call the `static` <xref:System.Web.Security.Membership.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method, which internally calls the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method. Alternatively, you can call this method directly, as shown in the Example section.
Forms authentication requires that the user specify their credentials through login controls provided by your application. You can retrieve the credentials and pass them to the <xref:System.Web.Security.Membership.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method. You can also pass in empty strings or `null` to use a credentials provider. For more information, see [How to: Implement User Login with Client Application Services](~/docs/framework/common-client-technologies/how-to-implement-user-login-with-client-application-services.md).
## Examples The following example code demonstrates how to use this method to validate the user by using an <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.IClientFormsAuthenticationCredentialsProvider> implementation. This example requires that you to configure your application to use a credentials provider. For more information, see [How to: Configure Client Application Services](~/docs/framework/common-client-technologies/how-to-configure-client-application-services.md).
[!code-csharp[ClientApplicationServices#306](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/ClientApplicationServices/CS/Class1.cs#306)] [!code-vb[ClientApplicationServices#306](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/ClientApplicationServices/VB/Class1.vb#306)]

Docs.exception: The property value is and the membership provider is unable to access the authentication service.
Docs.related: How to: Configure Client Application Services
How to: Implement User Login and Logout with Client Application Services

MemberSignature.Value: public bool ValidateUser (string username, string password, bool rememberMe);
.method public hidebysig instance bool ValidateUser(string username, string password, bool rememberMe) cil managed
Public Function ValidateUser (username As String, password As String, rememberMe As Boolean) As Boolean
public: bool ValidateUser(System::String ^ username, System::String ^ password, bool rememberMe);
override this.ValidateUser : string * string * bool -> bool

Docs.param: The name of the user to authenticate.
The password of the user to authenticate.

to store a hash of the password in the local data cache for offline use and for automatic reauthentication when the user authentication cookie expires; to disable offline login or to require users to reauthenticate when the cookie expires.
Docs.summary: Authenticates a user by using the specified user name and password, optionally storing a hash of the password in the local data cache.
Docs.returns: if the user was authenticated; otherwise, .

remarks.format:
## Remarks You can use client application services to validate users by using forms authentication. To validate users, you will typically call the `static` <xref:System.Web.Security.Membership.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method, which internally calls the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ValidateUser%28System.String%2CSystem.String%29?displayProperty=nameWithType> method. Alternatively, you can call the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method directly. You can call this overload to pass in a `rememberMe` value in addition to the `username` and `password` values.
## Examples The following example code demonstrates how to use this method to validate the user by using login controls in your application code. This example requires a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox> control named `usernameTextBox`, a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox> control named `passwordTextBox`, and a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.CheckBox> control named `rememberMeCheckBox`.
[!code-csharp[ClientApplicationServices#307](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/ClientApplicationServices/CS/Class1.cs#307)] [!code-vb[ClientApplicationServices#307](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/ClientApplicationServices/VB/Class1.vb#307)]

Docs.exception: The property value is and the membership provider is unable to access the authentication service.

How to: Implement User Login and Logout with Client Application Services

MemberSignature.Value: public static bool ValidateUser (string username, string password, string serviceUri);
.method public static hidebysig bool ValidateUser(string username, string password, string serviceUri) cil managed
Public Shared Function ValidateUser (username As String, password As String, serviceUri As String) As Boolean
public: static bool ValidateUser(System::String ^ username, System::String ^ password, System::String ^ serviceUri);
static member ValidateUser : string * string * string -> bool

Docs.param: The name of the user to authenticate.
The password of the user to authenticate.
The URI of the authentication service to use.
Docs.summary: Authenticates a user at the specified service URI by using the specified user name and password.
Docs.returns: if the user was authenticated; otherwise, .

remarks.format:
## Remarks You can use client application services to validate users by using forms authentication. To validate users, you will typically call the `static` <xref:System.Web.Security.Membership.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method, which internally calls the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method. Alternatively, you can call the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ValidateUser%2A?displayProperty=nameWithType> method directly. You can call this overload to access an authentication service at the location specified by the `serviceUri` parameter. Using this overload is an alternative to setting the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ServiceUri%2A> property and calling the <xref:System.Web.ClientServices.Providers.ClientFormsAuthenticationMembershipProvider.ValidateUser%28System.String%2CSystem.String%29> overload.
## Examples The following example code demonstrates how to use this method to validate the user through an authentication service at a specified location. The user credentials are retrieved from login controls in your application code. This example requires a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox> control named `usernameTextBox` and a <xref:System.Windows.Forms.TextBox> control named `passwordTextBox`.
[!code-csharp[ClientApplicationServices#308](~/samples/snippets/csharp/VS_Snippets_Winforms/ClientApplicationServices/CS/Class1.cs#308)] [!code-vb[ClientApplicationServices#308](~/samples/snippets/visualbasic/VS_Snippets_Winforms/ClientApplicationServices/VB/Class1.vb#308)]

Docs.exception: The property value is and the membership provider is unable to access the authentication service.

How to: Implement User Login and Logout with Client Application Services
